Introduction 

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) refers to a rare group of neoplasms arising from mature T cells that reside in the skin.  CTCL encompasses a variety of subtypes, with mycosis fungoides (MF) being the most common, followed by Sézary syndrome.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Lymphomas are a diverse group of neoplasms that can be categorized according to the cell of origin and stage of maturation (

table 1
).  CTCL appears to develop following the accumulation of genetic and epigenetic changes affecting cell growth and survival of mature CD4+ memory T cells that reside on the skin.  Although various types of genetic mutations can occur, chromosomal translocations and deletions appear to occur more frequently.  Combined with alterations in the tumor microenvironment leading to reduced immune surveillance, which allows for malignant transformation and clonal expansion.



The incidence of CTCL appears to peak around age 50-70, affecting males more than females.

Clinical presentation



Multiple subtypes of CTCL exist, and the presentation can vary between them.  The most common subtypes are mycosis fungiodes (MF) and Sézary syndrome.

Mycosis fungoides



The most common subtype, MF typically presents with persistent, slowly progressive skin lesions.  Patients usually first develop isolated hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches (flat discolored area of skin >1 cm) that may have scaling (

image 1
).  Some lesions may become plaques (well-defined, raised, palpable, flat-topped lesions >1 cm in diameter) (
image 2
).  Some patients may present with both patches and plaques (
image 3
), which may resemble other benign skin lesions (eg, eczema, psoriasis).  The skin is commonly pruritic and can become lichenified due to chronic scratching/rubbing (
image 4
).  As the disease progresses, tumors can develop (the term "mycosis fungoides" refers to the mushroom-like appearance of these tumors), representing deeper dermal infiltration by tumor cells (
image 5
).



The distribution of the lesions initially tends to be focal along sun-protected areas (buttocks (

image 6
), proximal lower extremities) but can become more generalized as the disease progresses.  Patients with more advanced disease may present with erythroderma (intense skin redness involving >90% body surface area) (
image 7
) or develop redundant skin along the face, creating a leonine appearance (
image 8
).  Other associated conditions include alopecia and secondary infections, particularly from chronic scratching.

Sézary syndrome



The second most common subtype of CTCL is Sézary syndrome.  Rather than patients experiencing the progression of skin lesions as described for MF, patients with Sézary syndrome are more likely to have widespread erythroderma at presentation.  Similar to MF, pruritus is common, which can be significantly debilitating due to the effects on sleep and mood.  Although both MF and Sézary syndrome have overlapping clinical features, the main distinguishing feature is the presence of significant numbers of circulating malignant cells, which can contribute to systemic symptoms (eg, fatigue, weight loss) and lymphadenopathy.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for CTCL includes other skin disorders and malignancies.

Inflammatory skin diseases



  • Conditions associated with scaly patches and/or plaques (eg, psoriasis, atopic dermatitis):  CTCL may present like these benign conditions.  However, persistence and/or progression despite treatment (eg, topical corticosteroids) is uncommon and would warrant further work-up (eg, skin biopsy).
  • Contact dermatitis:  Contact dermatitis may also present with an inflammatory rash, although it should be in a distribution consistent with direct contact with an offending source.
  • Other causes of erythroderma:  Other conditions, including hypersensitivity reactions to medications and infections (eg, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome), can also cause widespread exfoliative dermatitis.  The specific cause may be revealed through the history and/or skin biopsy.

Infectious diseases



  • Fungal infections (eg, tinea corporis):  Such infections can present with an erythematous rash with scaling but should respond to topical antifungal medications.
  • Scabies:  Scabies can be associated with significant pruritus and nail changes, particularly in crusted scabies, but the lesions should respond to treatment.

Other malignancies



  • Adult T-cell leukemia-lymphoma:  Adult T-cell leukemia-lymphoma is a mature peripheral T-cell malignancy that can also present with skin lesions.  It is strongly associated with the human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) within malignant cells and can be distinguished by testing for antibodies against the virus.
  • Other malignancies with skin components:  CTCL can be distinguished from most other malignancies that also have a skin component (eg, Langerhans cell histiocytosis) based on histopathologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings obtained via biopsy.

Diagnosis



CTCL should be considered in patients with chronic progressive skin lesions or diffuse erythroderma.  Evaluation involves:



  • Complete history and physical examination:  Complete history and physical examination can help estimate the extent of body surface area involved by lesions and assess for lymphadenopathy and/or organomegaly (more common in Sézary syndrome).
  • Skin biopsy should be obtained from the most indurated area of skin (multiple biopsies may be necessary).  Characteristic findings for CTCL include the following:
    • Histolopathology:  Lymphoid infiltrates occur within the epidermal layer (
      image 9
      ).
    • Immunophenotyping and molecular testing:  Characteristic cell surface markers (eg, CD4, CD30) confirm T-helper cell origin.  In addition, CTCL expresses CCR4, which is associated with the skin-homing ability of T cells.  Molecular testing confirms monoclonality by assessing T-cell–receptor rearrangements.
  • Complete blood count (CBC) and peripheral blood smear:  CBC can be used to evaluate for cytopenias and/or the presence of malignant cells (ie, Sézary cells [atypical T cells with cerebriform nuclei] (
    image 10
    )).  Molecular and immunophenotyping may also be obtained to confirm that the blood tumor cells match the skin tumor cells.  The presence of circulating malignant cells distinguishes Sézary syndrome from MF.
  • Imaging (eg, positron emission tomography and CT scan):  Imaging is performed to assess for lymph node involvement or involvement of visceral organs.  This should be considered if Sézary syndrome is suspected or if there are suggestive examination findings (eg, palpable lymph nodes).
  • Lymph node biopsy:  A biopsy should be obtained from any suspicious lymph nodes.  Bone marrow examination should also be considered if unexplained cytopenias exist.

Staging



Disease staging involves the TNMB classification, which is determined based on the combined results after evaluating the skin (T), lymph nodes (N), viscera (M), and blood (B).  In general:



  • Stage I:  Skin only, with minimal or no blood involvement.  No lymph node or visceral involvement.
  • Stage II:  Possibly more extensive skin involvement, minimal or no blood involvement, and some lymph node involvement.  No involvement of viscera.
  • Stage III:  Diffuse skin involvement, minimal or no blood involvement, potential lymph node involvement.  No involvement of viscera.
  • Stage IV:  Widespread involvement of the skin, blood, lymph nodes, and/or viscera.


Although patients with MF can present in any stage, patients with Sézary syndrome by definition have stage IV disease due to the diffuse tumor burden in the blood.

Management



Treatment is tailored to disease stage and subtype, ranging from skin-directed therapies for early-stage disease to systemic treatments for advanced stages.  There is no curative therapy, and the overall goal of management is symptom relief and disease control to prevent continued progression.



For all patients, supportive care is provided for pruritus, which can be debilitating.  Management includes the use of moisturizers, topical corticosteroids, and antihistamines.  Other agents that may be considered include gabapentin or naltrexone.  For those who develop secondary infection, diluted bleach baths and topical antibiotics may be used for mild cases, and systemic antibiotics are considered for more severe cases.



Early-stage CTCL generally involves skin-directed therapy and may include topical corticosteroids or topical therapies (eg, retinoids, alkylating agents) for pruritus.  Phototherapy or radiation therapy may be used for treatment.



Advanced-stage CTCL or refractory early-stage disease may include some treatments also used in early-stage disease but usually requires more intensive treatment, including multiple systemic options that are individualized based on symptoms and overall disease burden.  A few notable options include brentuximab vedotin (contains an antibody against CD30, which is expressed on T lymphocytes) antimetabolites (eg, methotrexate, pralatrexate), histone deacetylase inhibitors (eg, romidepsin), and mogamulizumab (a monoclonal antibody targeting CCR4, which is expressed on the surface of T-cell malignancies).  Extracorporeal photopheresis can be used in patients with blood involvement, and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be considered in patients with minimal comorbidities who have refractory/progressive advanced disease.

Prognosis



The prognosis of CTCL varies by stage.  Patients with early-stage MF may have an indolent course with long-term survival similar to that of the general population.  In contrast, patients with advanced-stage disease have a much worse prognosis with a high risk for relapse despite treatment.  Median survival for Sézary syndrome is 3-4 years.

Summary



Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) refers to a rare group of neoplasms arising from mature T cells that reside on the skin.  CTCL encompasses a variety of subtypes, including mycosis fungoides and Sézary syndrome, the two most common.  CTCL predominantly affects older adults, often presenting with persistent and slowly progressive skin lesions, often accompanied by pruritus.  Treatment is dependent on the extent of disease and may include topical medications or systemic chemotherapy.
